This data service offering consists of the algorithm to facilitate a descriptive analysis of protected customer data of a German SME, available for GDPR-compliant computation with a specific whitelisted algorithm to extract valuable business insights.

![Status](https://img.shields.io/badge/Service-Online%20%2F%20Available-green)
![Type](https://img.shields.io/badge/Type-Secure%20Computation-blue)
![Type](https://img.shields.io/badge/Domain-SME-blue)

This algorithm and the corresponding dataset are displayed in the [Minimal Viable Gaia-X Demonstrator Portal](https://portal.minimal-gaia-x.eu/asset/did:op:E4bE4AF489089bE4c199149A9f9D9C1fbEa138A8).

## About the Use Case

This use case illustrates how Compute-to-Data is leveraged to monetize sensible customer data in a GDPR-compliant way and build data-driven products on top of sensitive information.

Compute-to-Data (CtD) allows for privacy-preserving data-sharing, remote computation and data monetization and is a core feature and strong advantage of Ocean Protocol. CtD keeps the data on-premises and allows data consumers to run remote compute jobs on the data. Data owners keep full control as the data never leaves their premises and is only ever accessed by algorithms.
CtD resolves the tradeoff between using private data and the risks of exposing it. Newly monetized data creates new revenue streams for data publishers.
CtD is directly integrated into the MVG and third-party Portals, where data providers can opt to restrict the access type to “compute only”. Once data is made accessible, the compute job is brought to the data and executed on-premise. This is especially suitable to train AI models, calculate statistics or build business analytics use cases on private data without revealing them.

## Preview of the Result

This is one of the computation results being created without ever sharing the sensible customer information. Please find the full sample below or [here](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/foreverontheblockchain.pdf)

![Preview](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/foreverontheblockchain_preview.jpg)

## About this Data Service Offering

[safeFBDC](https://techquartier.com/fbdc), the Financial Big Data Cluster, joins the 2nd Gaia-X Hackathon to prototype first Gaia-X use cases for the financial sector. In collaboration with [deltaDAO AG](https://delta-dao.com) and [Ocean Protocol](https://oceanprotocol.com) the safeFBDC consortia will explore Compute-to-Data to enable develop a secure, legally compliant, and user-friendly financial data platform to advance machine-learning solutions across Europe’s financial ecosystem. In ensuring secure access to currently unavailable financial data, safeFBDC will be able to contribute substantially to building and securing the long-term operations and growth of a European data ecosystem. This is not limited to financial data, but also across many other industries to produce economically viable projects and develop data-based products.  

[- safeFBDC Portal -](https://safefbdc.portal.minimal-gaia-x.eu)

The first use case “AML detection on graphs” aims to advance the development of detection methods for previously undetected cross-institutional patterns in money laundering. 

## Use case description: 

Bank A provides its transaction data as input to create graphs of transactions across multiple banks. They get back suspicious transactions (and network excerpts) of their customers. They use this information for internal investigation and if the alert is confirmed they send a SAR (suspicious activity report) to FIU. The same process applies to Bank B. AI companies like spottixx GmbH provide the necessary algorithms and machine learning know-how to detect money laundring. To extend detection capabilities, the safeFBDC consortium acts as a trustee and executes the algorithm on on-demand pooled data in a trust (confidential computing) environment. This confidential computing environment can be created on-demand using Gaia-X trusted and transparent service offerings. After the computation is completed, the corresponding results are sent back to the banks for reporting and can be made available to regulatory authorities (e.g. BaFin) or prosecutive authorities (e.g. FIU). By using the Gaia-X Federation Services and state-of-the-art privacy preserving technology, only desired results are provided while the safeFBDC consortium always retains full control of the data and minimizes risk of data leaks.  

## Background

safeFBDC is a research project funded by the Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy (BMWi) with a three-year project duration (2021-2023). The consortium under the leadership of TechQuartier consists of eleven founding and 30+ associated partners covering a large part of the German financial industry and beyond.

The safeFBDC project aims to create a holistic platform concept that encompasses both a trustworthy IT infrastructure and forward-looking AI-driven business models for the financial industry. At the heart of this is a dedicated technology stack that enables sensitive data to be shared teleologically, i.e., for a specific purpose, across organizations. The data owner always decides for which purpose the data may be used, e.g., for specific use cases, centralized or decentralized learning. The interest in the successful realization of safeFBDC is not limited to actors of financial markets; it is intended to serve the greater public good. This is a unique opportunity to establish a strong data ecosystem for the financial services market in Germany and beyond.

## About this Data Service Offering

This data service offering consists of a traffic image classification algorithm, which identifies road safety relevant objects in a sample set of images. The algorithm uses features learned by a deep convolutional neural network to detect traffic related objects.  
  
The sample dataset and the whitelisted algorithm are listed in the [Minimal Viable Gaia-X Portal here](https://portal.minimal-gaia-x.eu/asset/did:op:3072145E0fDb31d1Aee26d985CA8873c1eB68088). 
  
This data service can be translated to many other use cases, i.e.  smart cities, robo taxis, autonomous driving use cases etc.  
  
## About the Use Case  
This use case demonstrates how participants from the mobility domain can use the Gaia-X market to train their Deep Learning models for traffic scene understanding and improve their road safety algorithms for autonomous driving. 

Robo taxis, autonomous busses, mapping or smart city applications require the availability of detailed information about road-related objects. The full dataset contains a large variance of city-, village-, country road-, federal road- and highway scenes in all weather conditions, daytimes and seasons throughout the year. It includes a variation of corner cases like extreme light, snow and rain to validate Deep Learning algorithms for traffic scene understanding.  

Algorithm and data providers can train and monetize their machine learning scripts by making them available in Gaia-X. At the same time consumers in Gaia-X can use existing and well-trained models for classification, analysis and forecasting without the need to share their data and/or acquire personnel or expensive services. The product can be used directly from the Gaia-X market.
Data providers approve AI algorithms to run on their data and then Compute-to-Data orchestrates remote computation and execution on data to train AI models while preserving the privacy of the data.  
Compute-to-Data (CtD) allows for privacy-preserving data-sharing, remote computation and data monetization and is a core feature and strong advantage of Ocean Protocol. CtD keeps the data on-premises and allows data consumers to run remote compute jobs on the data. Data owners keep full control as the data never leaves their premises and is only ever accessed by algorithms. CtD resolves the tradeoff between using private data and the risks of exposing it. Newly monetized data creates new revenue streams for data publishers. CtD is directly integrated into the Minimal Viable Gaia-X and third-party portals, where data providers can opt to restrict the access type to “compute only”. Once data is made accessible, the compute job is brought to the data and executed on-premise. This is especially suitable to train AI models, calculate statistics or build business analytics use cases on private data without revealing them.

Object detection is considered to be one of the most challenging tasks in the computer vision field. The algorithm YOLOv5 is a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) for performing object detection in real-time. CNNs are classifier-based systems that can process input images as structured arrays of data and identify patterns between them (view image below). YOLO has the advantage of being much faster than other networks and still maintains accuracy.

If you want to try this with your own image data you just need to publish a data service offering with a sample set of images in a ZIP file and whitelist this algorithm to use with your data. Please note that this image will be transferred into the CtD environment of the Minimal Viable Gaia-X if you did not contribute and specify your own Compute-to-Data cluster.

Collection of standardized brain surfaces in fsaverage space curated by templateflow in BIDS-style and retrieved via datalad.
## Details
The most common surface-based template is fsaverage. The spatial resolution of a surface template is determined by the linear divisions of an icosahedron (20-sided convex regular polygon; i.e., a d20 for the D&D folks) according to the following equation: if the number of linear divisions n = 64, you will end up with 20 * n**2 faces (81,920 faces/triangles, or 40,960 per hemisphere) and 2 + 10 * n**2 vertices per hemisphere (40,962). Common fsaverage resolutions are fsaverage (163,842 vertices per hemispheres), fsaverage6 (40,962 vertices per hemisphere), fsaverage5 (10,242 vertices per hemisphere).

Descriptive statistics based on Pandas `describe()`.

For numeric data, the result’s index will include `count`, `mean`, `std`, `min`, `max` as well as lower, 50, and upper `percentiles`. By default, the lower percentile is 25 and the upper percentile is 75. The 50 percentile is the same as the median.

For object data (e.g. strings or timestamps), the result’s index will include `count`, `unique`, `top`, and `freq`. The top is the most common value. The freq is the most common value’s frequency. Timestamps also include the first and last items.

This is part of the Fuji-SfM dataset, it includes the 12 raw images of part (1) of the whole dataset.

The Fuji-SfM dataset includes: (1) a set of 288 colour images and the corresponding annotations (apples segmentation masks) for training instance segmentation neural networks such as Mask-RCNN; (2) a set of 582 images used to generate the 3D model of 11 Fuji apple trees containing 1455 apples by using SfM; (3) the 3D point cloud of the scanned scene with the corresponding apple positions ground truth in global coordinates. This data allows the development, training, and test of fruit detection algorithms either based on RGB images, on coloured point clouds or on the combination of both types of data.

Methodology

The reader is referred to visit articles [1] and [2] for a description of methodology and further information about this dataset.

Aknowledgements

This work was partly funded by the Secretaria d’Universitats i Recerca del Departament d’Empresa i Coneixement de la Generalitat de Catalunya (grant 2017 SGR 646), the Spanish Ministry of Economy and Competitiveness (project AGL2013-48297-C2-2-R) and the Spanish Ministry of Science, Innovation and Universities (project RTI2018-094222-B-I00). Part of the work was also developed within the framework of the project TEC2016-75976-R, financed by the Spanish Ministry of Economy, Industry and Competitiveness and the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF). The Spanish Ministry of Education is thanked for Mr. J. Gené’s pre-doctoral fellowships (FPU15/03355). We would also like to thank Nufri (especially Santiago Salamero and Oriol Morreres) and Vicens Maquinària Agrícola S.A. for their support during data acquisition, and Ernesto Membrillo and Roberto Maturino for their support in dataset labelling.

This database is available only for research and educational purpose and not for any commercial use. If you use the database in any publications or reports, you must refer to the following papers:

[1] Gené-Mola J, Sanz-Cortiella R, Rosell-Polo JR, Morros J-R, Ruiz-Hidalgo J, Vilaplana V, , Gregorio E. 2020. Fruit detection and 3D location using instance segmentation neural networks and structure-from-motion photogrammetry. Computers and Electronics in Agriculture, 169 (2020), 105165. DOI: 10.1016/j.compag.2019.105165
[2] Gené-Mola J, Sanz-Cortiella R, Rosell-Polo JR, Morros J-R, Ruiz-Hidalgo J, Vilaplana V, , Gregorio E. 2020. Fuji-SfM dataset: a collection of annotated images and point clouds for Fuji apple detection and location using structure-from-motion photogrammetry. (Submitted)

## Important - This is the "quick" computation

This is the “quick” version for the 1st Gaia-X Hackathon. It runs much faster and only delivers a final result without the intermediate steps to illustrate the functionality of Compute-to-Data and the Data Exchange Logging Service and Data Audit Trails in Gaia-X.

### About the use case

The Orfeo toolbox (OTB) is a remote sensing image processing library. The project was initiated by the CNES (French  National  Center  for  Space  Studies)  in  2006  and  is  subject  to  continuous  development  by  private companies  and  the  open-source  community.  The  purpose  of  OTB  is  to  provide  users  of  Earth  observation data the necessary tools to use these images. Originally, the library targeted the very high spatial resolution images acquired by the Orfeo constellation (Pleiades in optics, Cosmo-Skymed [CSK] in radar, but also other sensors). The OTB consists of a set of classescoded in C++ and applications built upon these classes.

Orfeo ToolBox (OTB) is an open-source project for state-of-the-art remote sensing. Built on the shoulders of the open-source geospatial community, it can process high resolution optical, multispectral and radar images at the terabyte scale. A wide variety of applications are available: from ortho-rectification or pansharpening, all the way to classification, SAR processing, and much more!

OTB application features came from the C++ library classes. They meet the users’ demands through simplified access and factoring requirements in data processing. They allow, among other things, to carry out the following operations:

- Access  to  data:  read/write  most  satellite  image  formats,  access  metadata,  read/write vector formats (shp, kml, etc.), digital terrain models, lidar data;
- Basic image manipulation: extraction, pixel-to-pixel calculations;
- Filtering: signal processing for optical and radar imaging;
- Feature extraction: textures (Haralick, Structural Feature Set [SFS]), edge detection, points of interest,  alignments,  lines,  descriptors  (Scale-Invariant  Feature  Transform  [SIFT],  Speeded Up Robust Features [SURF]);  
- Image segmentation: region growing, watershed, level set, mean-shift;
- Classification:  K-means,  support  vector  machine,  random  forests,  as  well  asmost recent machine learning algorithms;
- Detection of changes between images;
- Orthorectification, cartographic projections;
- Calculation of radiometric indices: vegetation, water, soil, etc.

### Intended use

This application is used to process images from Sentinel-1 SLC IW and Sentinel 2 L2A over the metropolitan area around Marseille, France. The figure below shows the extent and location of the Sentinel 2 data (red), the Sentinel 1 data (yellow), and the area of interest (blue).

![dataset_sentinel_01](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_01.png)

Image: [https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/97e4c2954cc86043d4f02f9f99d4150b37fe49d8/dataset_sentinel_01.png](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/97e4c2954cc86043d4f02f9f99d4150b37fe49d8/dataset_sentinel_01.png)   

Sentinel-1 SLC IW: Single Look Complex (SLC) Interferometric Wide (IW) Swath products consist  of  focused  SAR  data  geo-referenced  using orbit  and  attitude  data  from  the satellite  and  provided  in  zero-Doppler  slant-range  geometry. Mundi  Web  Services provides  the  complete  collection,  with  fresh  free  data  ONLINE  from  January  2018  with global  coverage,  and  from  January  2017  for  Europe.  A  rolling  policy  of  12  months  for World  and  24  months  for  Europe  is  currently  applied. We  are  making more  data available every day. 

The  IW  SLC  product used  in  this  tutorial contains  one  image  per  sub-swath,  per polarization  channel,  for  a  total  of  three  images.  Each  sub-swath  image  consists  of  a series  of  bursts,  where  each  burst  was  processed  as  a  separate  SLC  image.  The individually focused complex burst images are included, in azimuth-time order, into a singlesub-swath image, with black-fill demarcation in between as can be seen below:

![dataset_sentinel_02](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_02.png)

Image: [https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_02.png](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_02.png)   

Sentinel-2: The   Sentinel-2   L2A   data   is   atmospherically   corrected   using   Sen2Cor processor and PlanetDEM Digital Elevation Model (DEM). L2A products are published 48–60 hours after the L1C products and available for you to browse throughour Mundi Web Services Geodata UI.The S2-L2A product used in this tutorial consists of only three images representing the true composite color that use bands of visible light red (B04), green (B03), and blue (B02) in  the corresponding red, green and blue color channels, resulting in a natural colored [result.It](http://result.It) is a good representation of the Earth as humans would see it naturally as can be seen below:

![dataset_sentinel_03](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_03.png)

Image: [https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_03.png](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_03.png)  

The data will be used for Unsupervised KMeans image classification. This is a composite application, using existing training and classification applications. The SharkKMeans model is used.

![dataset_sentinel_04](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_04.png)

[https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_04.png](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_04.png)  

This is the overall process until the image classification has been created and is available for download.

![dataset_sentinel_05](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_05.png)

Image: [https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_05.png](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_05.png)  

This algorithm is intended to be used in a Compute-to-Data environment, so you will not be able to directly access it. After processing the application you will be able to download the result.

If you want to download the sample files for your local installation and replication, you will need to open a free Mundi account here to access the satellite data: [https://mundiwebservices.com/](https://mundiwebservices.com/)   

If you need support, please use the Mundi Helpdesk: [https://mundiwebservices.com/contact](https://mundiwebservices.com/contact)

To actually view the result images from the computation you will need the Monteverdi Image Viewer that is available for Linux, Mac and Windows machines. It is included in the Orfeo Package here: [https://www.orfeo-toolbox.org/download/](https://www.orfeo-toolbox.org/download/)

The docker image can be accessed here: [https://mundiwebservices.com/service/cnes-orfeo-toolbox](https://mundiwebservices.com/service/cnes-orfeo-toolbox) and is provided by CNES (see below). To directly access the docker image you need to be logged in. You can access it here: 
[https://share.mundiwebservices.com/#browse/search/docker:6dfda0a843f4201d7c831731b2609aee](https://eur01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fshare.mundiwebservices.com%2F%23browse%2Fsearch%2Fdocker%3A6dfda0a843f4201d7c831731b2609aee&data=04|01|thierry.caminel%40atos.net|00a7d276ca3941ce0ce008d9631c6e93|33440fc6b7c7412cbb730e70b0198d5a|0|0|637649796028786485|Unknown|TWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D|1000&sdata=HVPh%2FXqCs2lF9h6khyNiNvHWedxteorP%2BVzKAnhL6Ng%3D&reserved=0)

additionalInformation.description:
### Important

This is the “full” version for the 1st Gaia-X Hackathon. It is very resource intensive and thus has been priced prohibitive as only a limited number of parallel runs can be handled by our demonstration infrastructure. This “full” version is used illustrate the functionality of Compute-to-Data and the Data Exchange Logging Service and Data Audit Trails in Gaia-X and that Compute-to-Data is able to handle intensive jobs.

### About the use case

The Orfeo toolbox (OTB) is a remote sensing image processing library. The project was initiated by the CNES (French  National  Center  for  Space  Studies)  in  2006  and  is  subject  to  continuous  development  by  private companies  and  the  open-source  community.  The  purpose  of  OTB  is  to  provide  users  of  Earth  observation data the necessary tools to use these images. Originally, the library targeted the very high spatial resolution images acquired by the Orfeo constellation (Pleiades in optics, Cosmo-Skymed [CSK] in radar, but also other sensors). The OTB consists of a set of classescoded in C++ and applications built upon these classes.

Orfeo ToolBox (OTB) is an open-source project for state-of-the-art remote sensing. Built on the shoulders of the open-source geospatial community, it can process high resolution optical, multispectral and radar images at the terabyte scale. A wide variety of applications are available: from ortho-rectification or pansharpening, all the way to classification, SAR processing, and much more!

OTB application features came from the C++ library classes. They meet the users’ demands through simplified access and factoring requirements in data processing. They allow, among other things, to carry out the following operations:

- Access  to  data:  read/write  most  satellite  image  formats,  access  metadata,  read/write vector formats (shp, kml, etc.), digital terrain models, lidar data;
- Basic image manipulation: extraction, pixel-to-pixel calculations;
- Filtering: signal processing for optical and radar imaging;
- Feature extraction: textures (Haralick, Structural Feature Set [SFS]), edge detection, points of interest,  alignments,  lines,  descriptors  (Scale-Invariant  Feature  Transform  [SIFT],  Speeded Up Robust Features [SURF]);  
- Image segmentation: region growing, watershed, level set, mean-shift;
- Classification:  K-means,  support  vector  machine,  random  forests,  as  well  asmost recent machine learning algorithms;
- Detection of changes between images;
- Orthorectification, cartographic projections;
- Calculation of radiometric indices: vegetation, water, soil, etc.

### Intended use

This application is used to process images from Sentinel-1 SLC IW and Sentinel 2 L2A over the metropolitan area around Marseille, France. The figure below shows the extent and location of the Sentinel 2 data (red), the Sentinel 1 data (yellow), and the area of interest (blue).

![dataset_sentinel_01](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/97e4c2954cc86043d4f02f9f99d4150b37fe49d8/dataset_sentinel_01.png)

Image: [https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/97e4c2954cc86043d4f02f9f99d4150b37fe49d8/dataset_sentinel_01.png](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/97e4c2954cc86043d4f02f9f99d4150b37fe49d8/dataset_sentinel_01.png)   

Sentinel-1 SLC IW: Single Look Complex (SLC) Interferometric Wide (IW) Swath products consist  of  focused  SAR  data  geo-referenced  using orbit  and  attitude  data  from  the satellite  and  provided  in  zero-Doppler  slant-range  geometry. Mundi  Web  Services provides  the  complete  collection,  with  fresh  free  data  ONLINE  from  January  2018  with global  coverage,  and  from  January  2017  for  Europe.  A  rolling  policy  of  12  months  for World  and  24  months  for  Europe  is  currently  applied. We  are  making more  data available every day. 

The  IW  SLC  product used  in  this  tutorial contains  one  image  per  sub-swath,  per polarization  channel,  for  a  total  of  three  images.  Each  sub-swath  image  consists  of  a series  of  bursts,  where  each  burst  was  processed  as  a  separate  SLC  image.  The individually focused complex burst images are included, in azimuth-time order, into a singlesub-swath image, with black-fill demarcation in between as can be seen below:

![dataset_sentinel_02](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_02.png)

Image: [https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_02.png](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_02.png)    

Sentinel-2: The   Sentinel-2   L2A   data   is   atmospherically   corrected   using   Sen2Cor processor and PlanetDEM Digital Elevation Model (DEM). L2A products are published 48–60 hours after the L1C products and available for you to browse throughour Mundi Web Services Geodata UI.The S2-L2A product used in this tutorial consists of only three images representing the true composite color that use bands of visible light red (B04), green (B03), and blue (B02) in  the corresponding red, green and blue color channels, resulting in a natural colored [result.It](http://result.It) is a good representation of the Earth as humans would see it naturally as can be seen below:

![dataset_sentinel_03](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_03.png)

Image: [https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_03.png](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_03.png)  

The data will be used for Unsupervised KMeans image classification. This is a composite application, using existing training and classification applications. The SharkKMeans model is used.

![dataset_sentinel_04]( https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_04.png)

[https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_04.png](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_04.png)

This is the overall process until the image classification has been created and is available for download.

![dataset_sentinel_05]( https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_05.png)

Image: [https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_05.png](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_05.png)  

This algorithm is intended to be used in a Compute-to-Data environment, so you will not be able to directly access it. After processing the application you will be able to download the result.

If you want to download the sample files for your local installation and replication, you will need to open a free Mundi account here to access the satellite data: [https://mundiwebservices.com](https://mundiwebservices.com/)   

If you need support, please use the Mundi Helpdesk: [https://mundiwebservices.com/contact](https://mundiwebservices.com/contact)   

The follwing data will be used:

**S1A_IW_SLC__1SDV_20200118T173043_20200118T173110_030858_038A7B_7AD7**

- Sensing Start Date: 2020-01-18T17:30:43Z 
- Processing Date: 2020-01-18T20:53:03Z 
- Sensor Mode: IW_ 
- Polarisation Channels: VV/VH 
- Relative Orbit Number: 161 
- Orbit Direction: ASCENDING 
- Online Status: OFFLINE 
- Timeliness Category: Fast_24h 
- Image Format: GEOTIFF  
- Product Datapack Size: 3.77 GB 

**S2B_MSIL1C_20210318T103649_N0209_R008_T31TFJ_20210318T143809**

- Sensing Start Date :  2021-03-18T10:36:49Z 
- Processing Date: 2021-03-18T22:05:12Z 
- Ingestion Date: 2021-03-18T23:49:35Z 
- Cloud Cover: 29.9953% 
- Tile Identifer: : 31TFJ 
- Relative Orbit Number : 8 
- Online Status: ONLINE 
- Image Format: JPEG2000 
- Product Datapack Size: 710.62 MB \n

The full tutorial can be downloaded here: [https://mundiwebservices.com/confluence/display/MPD/Orfeo+Toolbox+service?preview=/65820/983134/CWS-FUNC-MUT-099-EN-Interferometry%20with%20OTB-v1.1.pdf](https://mundiwebservices.com/confluence/display/MPD/Orfeo+Toolbox+service?preview=/65820/983134/CWS-FUNC-MUT-099-EN-Interferometry%20with%20OTB-v1.1.pdf)

To actually view the result images from the computation you will need the Monteverdi Image Viewer that is available for Linux, Mac and Windows machines. It is included in the Orfeo Package here: [https://www.orfeo-toolbox.org/download/](https://www.orfeo-toolbox.org/download/)

The docker image can be accessed here: [https://mundiwebservices.com/service/cnes-orfeo-toolbox](https://mundiwebservices.com/service/cnes-orfeo-toolbox) and is provided by CNES (see below). To directly access the docker image you need to be logged in. \n

You can access it here: [https://share.mundiwebservices.com/#browse/search/docker:6dfda0a843f4201d7c831731b2609aee](https://eur01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fshare.mundiwebservices.com%2F%23browse%2Fsearch%2Fdocker%3A6dfda0a843f4201d7c831731b2609aee&data=04|01|thierry.caminel%40atos.net|00a7d276ca3941ce0ce008d9631c6e93|33440fc6b7c7412cbb730e70b0198d5a|0|0|637649796028786485|Unknown|TWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D|1000&sdata=HVPh%2FXqCs2lF9h6khyNiNvHWedxteorP%2BVzKAnhL6Ng%3D&reserved=0)

## Important - This is the "quick" computation

This is the “quick” version for the 1st Gaia-X Hackathon. It runs much faster and only delivers a final result without the intermediate steps to illustrate the functionality of Compute-to-Data and the Data Exchange Logging Service and Data Audit Trails in Gaia-X.

### About the use case

The Orfeo toolbox (OTB) is a remote sensing image processing library. The project was initiated by the CNES (French  National  Center  for  Space  Studies)  in  2006  and  is  subject  to  continuous  development  by  private companies  and  the  open-source  community.  The  purpose  of  OTB  is  to  provide  users  of  Earth  observation data the necessary tools to use these images. Originally, the library targeted the very high spatial resolution images acquired by the Orfeo constellation (Pleiades in optics, Cosmo-Skymed [CSK] in radar, but also other sensors). The OTB consists of a set of classescoded in C++ and applications built upon these classes.

Orfeo ToolBox (OTB) is an open-source project for state-of-the-art remote sensing. Built on the shoulders of the open-source geospatial community, it can process high resolution optical, multispectral and radar images at the terabyte scale. A wide variety of applications are available: from ortho-rectification or pansharpening, all the way to classification, SAR processing, and much more!

OTB application features came from the C++ library classes. They meet the users’ demands through simplified access and factoring requirements in data processing. They allow, among other things, to carry out the following operations:

- Access  to  data:  read/write  most  satellite  image  formats,  access  metadata,  read/write vector formats (shp, kml, etc.), digital terrain models, lidar data;
- Basic image manipulation: extraction, pixel-to-pixel calculations;
- Filtering: signal processing for optical and radar imaging;
- Feature extraction: textures (Haralick, Structural Feature Set [SFS]), edge detection, points of interest,  alignments,  lines,  descriptors  (Scale-Invariant  Feature  Transform  [SIFT],  Speeded Up Robust Features [SURF]);  
- Image segmentation: region growing, watershed, level set, mean-shift;
- Classification:  K-means,  support  vector  machine,  random  forests,  as  well  asmost recent machine learning algorithms;
- Detection of changes between images;
- Orthorectification, cartographic projections;
- Calculation of radiometric indices: vegetation, water, soil, etc.

### Intended use

This application is used to process images from Sentinel-1 SLC IW and Sentinel 2 L2A over the metropolitan area around Marseille, France. The figure below shows the extent and location of the Sentinel 2 data (red), the Sentinel 1 data (yellow), and the area of interest (blue).

![dataset_sentinel_01](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_01.png)

Image: [https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/97e4c2954cc86043d4f02f9f99d4150b37fe49d8/dataset_sentinel_01.png](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/97e4c2954cc86043d4f02f9f99d4150b37fe49d8/dataset_sentinel_01.png)   

Sentinel-1 SLC IW: Single Look Complex (SLC) Interferometric Wide (IW) Swath products consist  of  focused  SAR  data  geo-referenced  using orbit  and  attitude  data  from  the satellite  and  provided  in  zero-Doppler  slant-range  geometry. Mundi  Web  Services provides  the  complete  collection,  with  fresh  free  data  ONLINE  from  January  2018  with global  coverage,  and  from  January  2017  for  Europe.  A  rolling  policy  of  12  months  for World  and  24  months  for  Europe  is  currently  applied. We  are  making more  data available every day. 

The  IW  SLC  product used  in  this  tutorial contains  one  image  per  sub-swath,  per polarization  channel,  for  a  total  of  three  images.  Each  sub-swath  image  consists  of  a series  of  bursts,  where  each  burst  was  processed  as  a  separate  SLC  image.  The individually focused complex burst images are included, in azimuth-time order, into a singlesub-swath image, with black-fill demarcation in between as can be seen below:

![dataset_sentinel_02](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_02.png)

Image: [https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_02.png](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_02.png)   

Sentinel-2: The   Sentinel-2   L2A   data   is   atmospherically   corrected   using   Sen2Cor processor and PlanetDEM Digital Elevation Model (DEM). L2A products are published 48–60 hours after the L1C products and available for you to browse throughour Mundi Web Services Geodata UI.The S2-L2A product used in this tutorial consists of only three images representing the true composite color that use bands of visible light red (B04), green (B03), and blue (B02) in  the corresponding red, green and blue color channels, resulting in a natural colored [result.It](http://result.It) is a good representation of the Earth as humans would see it naturally as can be seen below:

![dataset_sentinel_03](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_03.png)

Image: [https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_03.png](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_03.png)  

The data will be used for Unsupervised KMeans image classification. This is a composite application, using existing training and classification applications. The SharkKMeans model is used.

![dataset_sentinel_04](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_04.png)

[https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_04.png](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_04.png)  

This is the overall process until the image classification has been created and is available for download.

![dataset_sentinel_05](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_05.png)

Image: [https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_05.png](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_05.png)  

This algorithm is intended to be used in a Compute-to-Data environment, so you will not be able to directly access it. After processing the application you will be able to download the result.

If you want to download the sample files for your local installation and replication, you will need to open a free Mundi account here to access the satellite data: [https://mundiwebservices.com/](https://mundiwebservices.com/)   

If you need support, please use the Mundi Helpdesk: [https://mundiwebservices.com/contact](https://mundiwebservices.com/contact)   

The follwing data will be used:

**S1A_IW_SLC__1SDV_20200118T173043_20200118T173110_030858_038A7B_7AD7**

- Sensing Start Date: 2020-01-18T17:30:43Z
- Processing Date: 2020-01-18T20:53:03Z
- Sensor Mode: IW_
- Polarisation Channels | VV/VH
- Relative Orbit Number | 161
- Orbit Direction: ASCENDING
- Online Status: OFFLINE
- Timeliness Category: Fast_24h
- Image Format: GEOTIFF
- Product Datapack Size: 3.77 GB

**S2B_MSIL1C_20210318T103649_N0209_R008_T31TFJ_20210318T143809**

- Sensing Start Date: 2021-03-18T10:36:49Z
- Processing Date: 2021-03-18T22:05:12Z
- Ingestion Date: 2021-03-18T23:49:35Z
- Cloud Cover: 29.9953%
- Tile Identifer: 31TFJ
- Relative Orbit Number: 8
- Online Status: ONLINE
- Image Format: JPEG2000
- Product Datapack Size: 710.62 MB

The full tutorial can be downloaded here: [https://mundiwebservices.com/confluence/display/MPD/Orfeo+Toolbox+service?preview=/65820/983134/CWS-FUNC-MUT-099-EN-Interferometry%20with%20OTB-v1.1.pdf](https://mundiwebservices.com/confluence/display/MPD/Orfeo+Toolbox+service?preview=/65820/983134/CWS-FUNC-MUT-099-EN-Interferometry%20with%20OTB-v1.1.pdf)

To actually view the result images from the computation you will need the Monteverdi Image Viewer that is available for Linux, Mac and Windows machines. It is included in the Orfeo Package here: [https://www.orfeo-toolbox.org/download/](https://www.orfeo-toolbox.org/download/)

The docker image can be accessed here: [https://mundiwebservices.com/service/cnes-orfeo-toolbox](https://mundiwebservices.com/service/cnes-orfeo-toolbox) and is provided by CNES (see below). To directly access the docker image you need to be logged in. You can access it here: 
[https://share.mundiwebservices.com/#browse/search/docker:6dfda0a843f4201d7c831731b2609aee](https://eur01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fshare.mundiwebservices.com%2F%23browse%2Fsearch%2Fdocker%3A6dfda0a843f4201d7c831731b2609aee&data=04|01|thierry.caminel%40atos.net|00a7d276ca3941ce0ce008d9631c6e93|33440fc6b7c7412cbb730e70b0198d5a|0|0|637649796028786485|Unknown|TWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D|1000&sdata=HVPh%2FXqCs2lF9h6khyNiNvHWedxteorP%2BVzKAnhL6Ng%3D&reserved=0)

### About CNES

The Centre National d’Etudes Spatiales (CNES) is the government agency responsible for shaping and implementing France’s space policy in Europe. Its task is to invent the space systems of the future, bring space technologies to maturity and guarantee France’s independent access to space. ## About this Data Service Offering

This data service offering consists of the algorithm to facilitate a descriptive analysis of protected customer data of foreverontheblockchain, a German SME, available for GDPR-compliant computation with a specific whitelisted algorithm to extract valuable business insights.

The dataset can be found [here in the Foreverontheblockchain Demonstration Portal](https://forever.portal.minimal-gaia-x.eu/asset/did:op:17fB3b4B571351bf8368c6c7Bfe9766F548C7201)

The [Foreverontheblockchain Demonstration Portal](https://forever.portal.minimal-gaia-x.eu/) can be found here.

This algorithm and the corresponding datset are also displayed in the [Minimal Viable Gaia-X Demonstrator Portal](https://portal.minimal-gaia-x.eu/asset/did:op:0341b42ff77c65FBe46C64d9A0D65694B8FAc2D9).

## About the Use Case

This use case illustrates how Compute-to-Data is leveraged to monetize sensible customer data in a GDPR-compliant way and build data-driven products on top of sensitive information.

Compute-to-Data (CtD) allows for privacy-preserving data-sharing, remote computation and data monetization and is a core feature and strong advantage of Ocean Protocol. CtD keeps the data on-premises and allows data consumers to run remote compute jobs on the data. Data owners keep full control as the data never leaves their premises and is only ever accessed by algorithms.
CtD resolves the tradeoff between using private data and the risks of exposing it. Newly monetized data creates new revenue streams for data publishers.
CtD is directly integrated into the MVG and third-party Portals, where data providers can opt to restrict the access type to “compute only”. Once data is made accessible, the compute job is brought to the data and executed on-premise. This is especially suitable to train AI models, calculate statistics or build business analytics use cases on private data without revealing them.

## Preview of the Result

This is one of the computation results being created without ever sharing the sensible customer information. Please find the full sample below or [here](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/foreverontheblockchain.pdf)

![Preview](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/foreverontheblockchain_preview.jpg)

main.name: Data Fusion Dataset - Copernicus Sentinel-1 SLC IW and Sentinel 2 L2A

additionalInformation.description:
The dataset includes 615 apples scanned under in-field conditions at two different phenology stages: green apples at 70% of final size and red apples at advanced ripening. The data includes different fruit diameters -from 26.9 mm to 94.8 mm- and different fruit occlusion percentages -from 1.4 % to 99 %-.

An additional set of 25 apples with diameters from 39 mm to 97 mm were scanned in laboratory conditions. The resulting high-resolution 3D point clouds (provided in the dataset) are a 360° complete representation of the apples.

This file is part of:

Jordi Gené-Mola; Ricardo Sanz-Cortiella; Joan R. Rosell-Polo; Alexandre Escolà; Eduard Gregorio, 2021, "PFuji-Size dataset: photogrammetry-derived 3D point clouds of Fuji apples trees with annotations to evaluate fruit detection and size estimation methodologies", [https://doi.org/10.34810/data141](https://doi.org/10.34810/data141), Repositori de Dades de Recerca, V1

[safeFBDC](https://techquartier.com/fbdc), the Financial Big Data Cluster, joins the 2nd Gaia-X Hackathon to prototype first Gaia-X use cases for the financial sector. In collaboration with [deltaDAO AG](https://delta-dao.com) and [Ocean Protocol](https://oceanprotocol.com) the safeFBDC consortia will explore Compute-to-Data to enable develop a secure, legally compliant, and user-friendly financial data platform to advance machine-learning solutions across Europe’s financial ecosystem. In ensuring secure access to currently unavailable financial data, safeFBDC will be able to contribute substantially to building and securing the long-term operations and growth of a European data ecosystem. This is not limited to financial data, but also across many other industries to produce economically viable projects and develop data-based products.  

[- safeFBDC Portal -](https://safefbdc.portal.minimal-gaia-x.eu)

The first use case “AML detection on graphs” aims to advance the development of detection methods for previously undetected cross-institutional patterns in money laundering. 

## Use case description: 

Bank A provides its transaction data as input to create graphs of transactions across multiple banks. They get back suspicious transactions (and network excerpts) of their customers. They use this information for internal investigation and if the alert is confirmed they send a SAR (suspicious activity report) to FIU. The same process applies to Bank B. AI companies like spottixx GmbH provide the necessary algorithms and machine learning know-how to detect money laundring. To extend detection capabilities, the safeFBDC consortium acts as a trustee and executes the algorithm on on-demand pooled data in a trust (confidential computing) environment. This confidential computing environment can be created on-demand using Gaia-X trusted and transparent service offerings. After the computation is completed, the corresponding results are sent back to the banks for reporting and can be made available to regulatory authorities (e.g. BaFin) or prosecutive authorities (e.g. FIU). By using the Gaia-X Federation Services and state-of-the-art privacy preserving technology, only desired results are provided while the safeFBDC consortium always retains full control of the data and minimizes risk of data leaks.  

## Background

safeFBDC is a research project funded by the Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy (BMWi) with a three-year project duration (2021-2023). The consortium under the leadership of TechQuartier consists of eleven founding and 30+ associated partners covering a large part of the German financial industry and beyond.

The safeFBDC project aims to create a holistic platform concept that encompasses both a trustworthy IT infrastructure and forward-looking AI-driven business models for the financial industry. At the heart of this is a dedicated technology stack that enables sensitive data to be shared teleologically, i.e., for a specific purpose, across organizations. The data owner always decides for which purpose the data may be used, e.g., for specific use cases, centralized or decentralized learning. The interest in the successful realization of safeFBDC is not limited to actors of financial markets; it is intended to serve the greater public good. This is a unique opportunity to establish a strong data ecosystem for the financial services market in Germany and beyond.

![Type](https://img.shields.io/badge/Domain-Mobility-blue)

## About this Data Service Offering

This data service offering consists of a real-time object detection algorithm, which identifies specific objects in a sample set of videos and images. The algorithm uses features learned by a deep convolutional neural network to detect an object. 

The sample dataset and the whitelisted algorithm are listed in the [Minimal Viable Gaia-X Portal here](https://portal.minimal-gaia-x.eu/asset/did:op:11c49877195B29Cd325cB33B667b0e3Be05Fe528).

This YOLOv5 algorithm is listed in the [Minimal Viable Gaia-X Portal here](https://portal.minimal-gaia-x.eu/asset/did:op:fc08c8c62b2ef8f4ee594558aB7cD50904B8BF78).

This data service can be translated to many other use cases, i.e. traffic detection, smart cities, agricultural use cases etc. 

## About the Use Case 

This use case demonstrates how algorithm and data providers can train and monetize their machine learning scripts by making them available in Gaia-X. At the same time consumers in Gaia-X can use existing and well-trained models for classification, analysis and forecasting without the need to share their data and/or acquire personnel or expensive services. The product can be used directly from the Gaia-X market. 

Object detection is considered to be one of the most challenging tasks in the computer vision field. The algorithm YOLOv5 is a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) for performing object detection in real-time. CNNs are classifier-based systems that can process input images as structured arrays of data and identify patterns between them (view image below). YOLO has the advantage of being much faster than other networks and still maintains accuracy. 

Data providers approve AI algorithms to run on their data and then Compute-to-Data orchestrates remote computation and execution on data to train AI models while preserving the privacy of the data. 

Compute-to-Data (CtD) allows for privacy-preserving data-sharing, remote computation and data monetization and is a core feature and strong advantage of Ocean Protocol. CtD keeps the data on-premises and allows data consumers to run remote compute jobs on the data. Data owners keep full control as the data never leaves their premises and is only ever accessed by algorithms. CtD resolves the tradeoff between using private data and the risks of exposing it. Newly monetized data creates new revenue streams for data publishers. CtD is directly integrated into the Minimal Viable Gaia-X and third-party portals, where data providers can opt to restrict the access type to “compute only”. Once data is made accessible, the compute job is brought to the data and executed on-premise. This is especially suitable to train AI models, calculate statistics or build business analytics use cases on private data without revealing them.  

## Preview of the Results

These images show the results of the real-time object detection algorithm: 

 ![Image Example 3](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/blob/main/yolov5_traffic_video.jpg?raw=true)
You can watch the  [Video here](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/deltaDAO/files/main/Real_time_traffic_video.mp4).

 ![Image Example 1](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/image_classification_1.jpg)

 ![Image Example 2](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/image_classification_2.jpg)

## How to try this with your own data

If you want to try this with your own image data you just need to publish a data service offering with a sample set of images in a ZIP file and whitelist this algorithm to use with your data. Please note that this image will be transferred into the CtD environment of the Minimal Viable Gaia-X if you did not contribute and specify your own Compute-to-Data cluster.

Data providers approve AI algorithms to run on their data and then Compute-to-Data orchestrates remote computation and execution on data to train AI models while preserving the privacy of the data. 

Compute-to-Data (CtD) allows for privacy-preserving data-sharing, remote computation and data monetization and is a core feature and strong advantage of Ocean Protocol. CtD keeps the data on-premises and allows data consumers to run remote compute jobs on the data. Data owners keep full control as the data never leaves their premises and is only ever accessed by algorithms. CtD resolves the tradeoff between using private data and the risks of exposing it. Newly monetized data creates new revenue streams for data publishers. CtD is directly integrated into the Minimal Viable Gaia-X and third-party portals, where data providers can opt to restrict the access type to “compute only”. Once data is made accessible, the compute job is brought to the data and executed on-premise. This is especially suitable to train AI models, calculate statistics or build business analytics use cases on private data without revealing them.

## The Vision

The future of data markets is embedded in the European Digital Single Market and the Gaia-X initiative, providing a European common infrastructure for data services. The challenge is to leverage the enormous potential of data without compromising European values, such as privacy of personal information, openness, inclusiveness, transparency and a cooperation based on trust in common values. To ensure this we need to engage, cooperate and come up with practical solutions that help us to achieve these goals for a better future and a new data economy for everyone.

## Specifications

Data is in JSON format. The data is randomly generated "weather" data in the following format:
```
{
  "date": [...],
  "temperature": [...],
  "humidity": [...],
  "rain": [...],
  "windSpeed": [...],
  "windDir": [...],
  "invalidTest": ""
}
```
Each key is assigned to an array of values, except the `invalidTest` key, which demonstrates an invalid value for testing purposes with our algorithm: [Demonstrator Algorithm 🧮 A European Data Economy in 2021](https://market001.delta-dao.com/asset/did:op:Fe0f741E188F025178BCFAeef7cE0854FaAF4d86)

The data is generated using the following configuration:
```
{
  temperature: {
    min: -10,
    max: 35
  },
  humidity: {
    min: 40,
    max: 100
  },
  rain: {
    min: 0,
    max: 20
  },
  windSpeed: {
    min: 0,
    max: 12
  },
  windDir: ["N", "NE", "E", "SE", "S", "SW", "W", "NW"]
}
```

This data service offering consists of a traffic image classification algorithm, which identifies road safety relevant objects in a sample set of images. The algorithm uses features learned by a deep convolutional neural network to detect traffic related objects.  

![Status](https://img.shields.io/badge/Service-Online%20%2F%20Available-green)
![Type](https://img.shields.io/badge/Type-Machine%20Learning-blue)
![Type](https://img.shields.io/badge/Domain-Mobility-blue)
  
The sample dataset and the whitelisted algorithm are listed in the [Minimal Viable Gaia-X Portal here](https://portal.minimal-gaia-x.eu/asset/did:op:d0bBC407c5Aa10d7Fd729A4bc00a9DC43535Cfe0). 
  
This data service can be translated to many other use cases, i.e.  smart cities, robo taxis, autonomous driving use cases etc.  
  
## About the Use Case  
This use case demonstrates how participants from the mobility domain can use the Gaia-X market to train their Deep Learning models for traffic scene understanding and improve their road safety algorithms for autonomous driving. 

Robo taxis, autonomous busses, mapping or smart city applications require the availability of detailed information about road-related objects. The full dataset contains a large variance of city-, village-, country road-, federal road- and highway scenes in all weather conditions, daytimes and seasons throughout the year. It includes a variation of corner cases like extreme light, snow and rain to validate Deep Learning algorithms for traffic scene understanding.  

Algorithm and data providers can train and monetize their machine learning scripts by making them available in Gaia-X. At the same time consumers in Gaia-X can use existing and well-trained models for classification, analysis and forecasting without the need to share their data and/or acquire personnel or expensive services. The product can be used directly from the Gaia-X market.

CtD keeps the data on-premises and allows data consumers to run remote compute jobs on the data. Data owners keep full control as the data never leaves their premises and is only ever accessed by algorithms. CtD resolves the tradeoff between using private data and the risks of exposing it. Newly monetized data creates new revenue streams for data publishers. CtD is directly integrated into the Minimal Viable Gaia-X and third-party portals, where data providers can opt to restrict the access type to “compute only”. Once data is made accessible, the compute job is brought to the data and executed on-premise. This is especially suitable to train AI models, calculate statistics or build business analytics use cases on private data without revealing them.

## USE CASE: Heat-demand-ML
For demonstrating the use-case of the GAIA-X infrastructure with a payload example we picked a Machine Learning (ML) use case of our own.

The ML use case is used for the prediction of the heat demand depending on the weather.
The project contains two applications:
- one for the training
- one for the inference.

They both have their own Docker images, which are built in the context of this hackathon and uploaded to the gitlab registry:


https://gitlab.com/gaia-x/gaia-x-community/gx-hackathon/heat-demand-ml

![heat](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/deltaDAO/files/main/heatdemand.JPG)
For training the ML-model, we use the historical heat demand data from our data centers as well as the historical weather data from the location. Following, we leverage the model to do an inference on the weather forecast data to predict the future heat demand of the data center location. For the SunRISE project, the output of the ML inference would we used as input for the orchestration tool krake (https://gitlab.com/rak-n-rok/krake
) to manage our cloud infrastructure and schedule applications.

## SunRISE Project machine learning Goal as use-case during the hackathon:
Cloud&Heat is looking into optimizing the placement of non-time critical, long running compute jobs,
by increasing the energy-efficiency by predicting the hot water demand and shifting the computational load to the respective sites. Reducing the carbon footprint by using a high amount
of green energy could be considered at a later stage. The goal of the use case is to forecast the energy-efficiency of Cloud&Heat data centers, leveraging metrics such as the local heat demand. In a later stage the current carbon footprint of the energy used to power the data center (gCO2/KW), could be assessed, and optimized.

This use case enables the possibility to predict when and where a compute job will run, providing the
end user with an estimation of the end of compute date. Therefore, the output of the energy efficiency forecast of each data center is provided to Cloud&Heat on the cloud platform. Leveraging this, Cloud&Heat can schedule compute jobs at specific locations and times to optimize the overall energy efficiency of its infrastructure. To estimate the energy-efficiency of a site the following is leveraged:

- Local heat demand: provided by Cloud&Heat datacenter
- Public weather forecast to predict the future heat demand, which can also be used to estimate the local production of renewable energy and therefore the carbon footprint of the energy available for the data center

The finalization of this ML Goal will be using homomorphic encryption. For the ease of using this during the hackathon the encryption part was left out.




## SunRISE Project

Project SunRISE (Shared IoT Security) is a European funded project under the label of Penta. Project SunRISE aims to develop secure end-to-end system solutions, based on the use of Security Intelligence Data (SID) for Machine Learning (ML). Research on novel Privacy-Preserving Technologies (PET) will allow the combined usage of data across clients or industrial competitors, enabling a new level of (shared) security.

Third parties that provide Machine Learning as a Service (MLaaS) will be able to utilize privacy-sensitive customer data in a way that is compliant with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). IoT devices, which are usually easy prey for hackers are protected with an immutable, hard-coded, unique identifier ensuring the authenticity.

More information: https://www.project-sunrise.eu/

The dataset contains a list of all blocks that were added to the Gaia-X DLT from  30/09/21, 12:00 AM UTC until 31/09/21 10:30 PM UTC saved as a simple JSON file. 

**Data structure**
```
{
   currentBlockNumber: Number,
   node: String,
   timestamp: Date,
   transactions: Array
}
```

**currentBlockNumber**.  This is the number of the block to find it in the history. A block could also be identified through its hash. Both values (block number and hash) are unique. 

**node.** An Gaia-X account address encoded as HEX. It represents the node that created the block. 

**timestamp**. A Unix timestamp when the block was created. 

**transactions**. An array of all transaction hashes for that specific block. These hashes are unique and can be used to retrieve detailed information about a specific transaction.

This is the “quick” version for the 1st Gaia-X Hackathon. It runs much faster and only delivers a final result without the intermediate steps to illustrate the functionality of Compute-to-Data and the Data Exchange Logging Service and Data Audit Trails in Gaia-X.

![Status](https://img.shields.io/badge/Service-Retired%20%2F%20Offline-red)

![Type](https://img.shields.io/badge/Type-Machine%20Learning-blue)

![Type](https://img.shields.io/badge/Domain-Geoinformation-blue)

![Type](https://img.shields.io/badge/Domain-Agriculture-blue)


### About the use case

The Orfeo toolbox (OTB) is a remote sensing image processing library. The project was initiated by the CNES (French  National  Center  for  Space  Studies)  in  2006  and  is  subject  to  continuous  development  by  private companies  and  the  open-source  community.  The  purpose  of  OTB  is  to  provide  users  of  Earth  observation data the necessary tools to use these images. Originally, the library targeted the very high spatial resolution images acquired by the Orfeo constellation (Pleiades in optics, Cosmo-Skymed [CSK] in radar, but also other sensors). The OTB consists of a set of classescoded in C++ and applications built upon these classes.

Orfeo ToolBox (OTB) is an open-source project for state-of-the-art remote sensing. Built on the shoulders of the open-source geospatial community, it can process high resolution optical, multispectral and radar images at the terabyte scale. A wide variety of applications are available: from ortho-rectification or pansharpening, all the way to classification, SAR processing, and much more!

OTB application features came from the C++ library classes. They meet the users’ demands through simplified access and factoring requirements in data processing. They allow, among other things, to carry out the following operations:

- Access  to  data:  read/write  most  satellite  image  formats,  access  metadata,  read/write vector formats (shp, kml, etc.), digital terrain models, lidar data;
- Basic image manipulation: extraction, pixel-to-pixel calculations;
- Filtering: signal processing for optical and radar imaging;
- Feature extraction: textures (Haralick, Structural Feature Set [SFS]), edge detection, points of interest,  alignments,  lines,  descriptors  (Scale-Invariant  Feature  Transform  [SIFT],  Speeded Up Robust Features [SURF]);  
- Image segmentation: region growing, watershed, level set, mean-shift;
- Classification:  K-means,  support  vector  machine,  random  forests,  as  well  asmost recent machine learning algorithms;
- Detection of changes between images;
- Orthorectification, cartographic projections;
- Calculation of radiometric indices: vegetation, water, soil, etc.

### Intended use

This application is used to process images from Sentinel-1 SLC IW and Sentinel 2 L2A over the metropolitan area around Marseille, France. The figure below shows the extent and location of the Sentinel 2 data (red), the Sentinel 1 data (yellow), and the area of interest (blue).

![dataset_sentinel_01](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_01.png)

Image: [https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/97e4c2954cc86043d4f02f9f99d4150b37fe49d8/dataset_sentinel_01.png](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/97e4c2954cc86043d4f02f9f99d4150b37fe49d8/dataset_sentinel_01.png)   

Sentinel-1 SLC IW: Single Look Complex (SLC) Interferometric Wide (IW) Swath products consist  of  focused  SAR  data  geo-referenced  using orbit  and  attitude  data  from  the satellite  and  provided  in  zero-Doppler  slant-range  geometry. Mundi  Web  Services provides  the  complete  collection,  with  fresh  free  data  ONLINE  from  January  2018  with global  coverage,  and  from  January  2017  for  Europe.  A  rolling  policy  of  12  months  for World  and  24  months  for  Europe  is  currently  applied. We  are  making more  data available every day.

# Metadata QUICK ATOS application



## Title

QUICK - Copernicus Sentinel Data Fusion with CNES Orfeo toolbox

## Keywords

GaiaX, space, imaging, remote sensing, application, hackathon, demonstration, OTB, ESA, Copernicus, SAR

## Timeout

1 day

## Description

Important:

This is the “quick” version for the 1st Gaia-X Hackathon. It runs much faster and only delivers a final result without the intermediate steps to illustrate the functionality of Compute-to-Data and the Data Exchange Logging Service and Data Audit Trails in Gaia-X.

### About the use case

The Orfeo toolbox (OTB) is a remote sensing image processing library. The project was initiated by the CNES (French  National  Center  for  Space  Studies)  in  2006  and  is  subject  to  continuous  development  by  private companies  and  the  open-source  community.  The  purpose  of  OTB  is  to  provide  users  of  Earth  observation data the necessary tools to use these images. Originally, the library targeted the very high spatial resolution images acquired by the Orfeo constellation (Pleiades in optics, Cosmo-Skymed [CSK] in radar, but also other sensors). The OTB consists of a set of classescoded in C++ and applications built upon these classes.

Orfeo ToolBox (OTB) is an open-source project for state-of-the-art remote sensing. Built on the shoulders of the open-source geospatial community, it can process high resolution optical, multispectral and radar images at the terabyte scale. A wide variety of applications are available: from ortho-rectification or pansharpening, all the way to classification, SAR processing, and much more!

OTB application features came from the C++ library classes. They meet the users’ demands through simplified access and factoring requirements in data processing. They allow, among other things, to carry out the following operations:

- Access  to  data:  read/write  most  satellite  image  formats,  access  metadata,  read/write vector formats (shp, kml, etc.), digital terrain models, lidar data;
- Basic image manipulation: extraction, pixel-to-pixel calculations;
- Filtering: signal processing for optical and radar imaging;
- Feature extraction: textures (Haralick, Structural Feature Set [SFS]), edge detection, points of interest,  alignments,  lines,  descriptors  (Scale-Invariant  Feature  Transform  [SIFT],  Speeded Up Robust Features [SURF]);  
- Image segmentation: region growing, watershed, level set, mean-shift;
- Classification:  K-means,  support  vector  machine,  random  forests,  as  well  asmost recent machine learning algorithms;
- Detection of changes between images;
- Orthorectification, cartographic projections;
- Calculation of radiometric indices: vegetation, water, soil, etc.

### Intended use

This application is used to process images from Sentinel-1 SLC IW and Sentinel 2 L2A over the metropolitan area around Marseille, France. The figure below shows the extent and location of the Sentinel 2 data (red), the Sentinel 1 data (yellow), and the area of interest (blue).



![dataset_sentinel_01](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_01.png)

Image: https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/97e4c2954cc86043d4f02f9f99d4150b37fe49d8/dataset_sentinel_01.png   

Sentinel-1 SLC IW: Single Look Complex (SLC) Interferometric Wide (IW) Swath products consist  of  focused  SAR  data  geo-referenced  using orbit  and  attitude  data  from  the satellite  and  provided  in  zero-Doppler  slant-range  geometry. Mundi  Web  Services provides  the  complete  collection,  with  fresh  free  data  ONLINE  from  January  2018  with global  coverage,  and  from  January  2017  for  Europe.  A  rolling  policy  of  12  months  for World  and  24  months  for  Europe  is  currently  applied. We  are  making more  data available every day. 

The  IW  SLC  product used  in  this  tutorial contains  one  image  per  sub-swath,  per polarization  channel,  for  a  total  of  three  images.  Each  sub-swath  image  consists  of  a series  of  bursts,  where  each  burst  was  processed  as  a  separate  SLC  image.  The individually focused complex burst images are included, in azimuth-time order, into a singlesub-swath image, with black-fill demarcation in between as can be seen below:

![dataset_sentinel_02](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_02.png)

Image: https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_02.png   

Sentinel-2: The   Sentinel-2   L2A   data   is   atmospherically   corrected   using   Sen2Cor processor and PlanetDEM Digital Elevation Model (DEM). L2A products are published 48–60 hours after the L1C products and available for you to browse throughour Mundi Web Services Geodata UI.The S2-L2A product used in this tutorial consists of only three images representing the true composite color that use bands of visible light red (B04), green (B03), and blue (B02) in  the corresponding red, green and blue color channels, resulting in a natural colored [result.It](http://result.It) is a good representation of the Earth as humans would see it naturally as can be seen below:

![dataset_sentinel_03](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_03.png)

Image: https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_03.png  

The data will be used for Unsupervised KMeans image classification. This is a composite application, using existing training and classification applications. The SharkKMeans model is used.

Mundi  Web  Services provides  the  complete  collection,  with  fresh  free  data  ONLINE  from  January  2018  with global  coverage,  and  from  January  2017  for  Europe.  A  rolling  policy  of  12  months  for World  and  24  months  for  Europe  is  currently  applied. We  are  making more  data available every day. 

The  IW  SLC  product used  in  this  tutorial contains  one  image  per  sub-swath,  per polarization  channel,  for  a  total  of  three  images.  Each  sub-swath  image  consists  of  a series  of  bursts,  where  each  burst  was  processed  as  a  separate  SLC  image.  The individually focused complex burst images are included, in azimuth-time order, into a singlesub-swath image, with black-fill demarcation in between as can be seen below:

![dataset_sentinel_02](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_02.png)

Image: https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_02.png   

Sentinel-2: The   Sentinel-2   L2A   data   is   atmospherically   corrected   using   Sen2Cor processor and PlanetDEM Digital Elevation Model (DEM). L2A products are published 48–60 hours after the L1C products and available for you to browse throughour Mundi Web Services Geodata UI.The S2-L2A product used in this tutorial consists of only three images representing the true composite color that use bands of visible light red (B04), green (B03), and blue (B02) in  the corresponding red, green and blue color channels, resulting in a natural colored [result.It](http://result.It) is a good representation of the Earth as humans would see it naturally as can be seen below:

![dataset_sentinel_03](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_03.png)

Image: https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_03.png  

The data will be used for Unsupervised KMeans image classification. This is a composite application, using existing training and classification applications. The SharkKMeans model is used.

![dataset_sentinel_04](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_04.png)

https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_04.png  

This is the overall process until the image classification has been created and is available for download.

![dataset_sentinel_05](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_05.png)

Image: https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_05.png  

This algorithm is intended to be used in a Compute-to-Data environment, so you will not be able to directly access it. After processing the application you will be able to download the result.

additionalInformation.description:
# Metadata QUICK ATOS dataset



## Title

QUICK - Copernicus Sentinel Data Fusion with CNES Orfeo toolbox

## Keywords

GaiaX, space, imaging, remote sensing, application, hackathon, demonstration, OTB, ESA, Copernicus, SAR

## Timeout

1 day

## Description

Important:

This is the “quick” version for the 1st Gaia-X Hackathon. It runs much faster and only delivers a final result without the intermediate steps to illustrate the functionality of Compute-to-Data and the Data Exchange Logging Service and Data Audit Trails in Gaia-X.

### About the use case

The Orfeo toolbox (OTB) is a remote sensing image processing library. The project was initiated by the CNES (French  National  Center  for  Space  Studies)  in  2006  and  is  subject  to  continuous  development  by  private companies  and  the  open-source  community.  The  purpose  of  OTB  is  to  provide  users  of  Earth  observation data the necessary tools to use these images. Originally, the library targeted the very high spatial resolution images acquired by the Orfeo constellation (Pleiades in optics, Cosmo-Skymed [CSK] in radar, but also other sensors). The OTB consists of a set of classescoded in C++ and applications built upon these classes.

Orfeo ToolBox (OTB) is an open-source project for state-of-the-art remote sensing. Built on the shoulders of the open-source geospatial community, it can process high resolution optical, multispectral and radar images at the terabyte scale. A wide variety of applications are available: from ortho-rectification or pansharpening, all the way to classification, SAR processing, and much more!

OTB application features came from the C++ library classes. They meet the users’ demands through simplified access and factoring requirements in data processing. They allow, among other things, to carry out the following operations:

- Access  to  data:  read/write  most  satellite  image  formats,  access  metadata,  read/write vector formats (shp, kml, etc.), digital terrain models, lidar data;
- Basic image manipulation: extraction, pixel-to-pixel calculations;
- Filtering: signal processing for optical and radar imaging;
- Feature extraction: textures (Haralick, Structural Feature Set [SFS]), edge detection, points of interest,  alignments,  lines,  descriptors  (Scale-Invariant  Feature  Transform  [SIFT],  Speeded Up Robust Features [SURF]);  
- Image segmentation: region growing, watershed, level set, mean-shift;
- Classification:  K-means,  support  vector  machine,  random  forests,  as  well  asmost recent machine learning algorithms;
- Detection of changes between images;
- Orthorectification, cartographic projections;
- Calculation of radiometric indices: vegetation, water, soil, etc.

### Intended use

This application is used to process images from Sentinel-1 SLC IW and Sentinel 2 L2A over the metropolitan area around Marseille, France. The figure below shows the extent and location of the Sentinel 2 data (red), the Sentinel 1 data (yellow), and the area of interest (blue).

Mundi  Web  Services provides  the  complete  collection,  with  fresh  free  data  ONLINE  from  January  2018  with global  coverage,  and  from  January  2017  for  Europe.  A  rolling  policy  of  12  months  for World  and  24  months  for  Europe  is  currently  applied. We  are  making more  data available every day. 

The  IW  SLC  product used  in  this  tutorial contains  one  image  per  sub-swath,  per polarization  channel,  for  a  total  of  three  images.  Each  sub-swath  image  consists  of  a series  of  bursts,  where  each  burst  was  processed  as  a  separate  SLC  image.  The individually focused complex burst images are included, in azimuth-time order, into a singlesub-swath image, with black-fill demarcation in between as can be seen below:

![dataset_sentinel_02](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_02.png)

Image: https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_02.png   

Sentinel-2: The   Sentinel-2   L2A   data   is   atmospherically   corrected   using   Sen2Cor processor and PlanetDEM Digital Elevation Model (DEM). L2A products are published 48–60 hours after the L1C products and available for you to browse throughour Mundi Web Services Geodata UI.The S2-L2A product used in this tutorial consists of only three images representing the true composite color that use bands of visible light red (B04), green (B03), and blue (B02) in  the corresponding red, green and blue color channels, resulting in a natural colored [result.It](http://result.It) is a good representation of the Earth as humans would see it naturally as can be seen below:

![dataset_sentinel_03](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_03.png)

The data will be used for Unsupervised KMeans image classification. This is a composite application, using existing training and classification applications. The SharkKMeans model is used.
