Originally, the library targeted the very high spatial resolution images acquired by the Orfeo constellation (Pleiades in optics, Cosmo-Skymed [CSK] in radar, but also other sensors). The OTB consists of a set of classescoded in C++ and applications built upon these classes.

Orfeo ToolBox (OTB) is an open-source project for state-of-the-art remote sensing. Built on the shoulders of the open-source geospatial community, it can process high resolution optical, multispectral and radar images at the terabyte scale. A wide variety of applications are available: from ortho-rectification or pansharpening, all the way to classification, SAR processing, and much more!

OTB application features came from the C++ library classes. They meet the users’ demands through simplified access and factoring requirements in data processing. They allow, among other things, to carry out the following operations:

- Access  to  data:  read/write  most  satellite  image  formats,  access  metadata,  read/write vector formats (shp, kml, etc.), digital terrain models, lidar data;
- Basic image manipulation: extraction, pixel-to-pixel calculations;
- Filtering: signal processing for optical and radar imaging;
- Feature extraction: textures (Haralick, Structural Feature Set [SFS]), edge detection, points of interest,  alignments,  lines,  descriptors  (Scale-Invariant  Feature  Transform  [SIFT],  Speeded Up Robust Features [SURF]);  
- Image segmentation: region growing, watershed, level set, mean-shift;
- Classification:  K-means,  support  vector  machine,  random  forests,  as  well  asmost recent machine learning algorithms;
- Detection of changes between images;
- Orthorectification, cartographic projections;
- Calculation of radiometric indices: vegetation, water, soil, etc.

### Intended use

This application is used to process images from Sentinel-1 SLC IW and Sentinel 2 L2A over the metropolitan area around Marseille, France. The figure below shows the extent and location of the Sentinel 2 data (red), the Sentinel 1 data (yellow), and the area of interest (blue).

![dataset_sentinel_01](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/97e4c2954cc86043d4f02f9f99d4150b37fe49d8/dataset_sentinel_01.png)

Image: [https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/97e4c2954cc86043d4f02f9f99d4150b37fe49d8/dataset_sentinel_01.png](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/97e4c2954cc86043d4f02f9f99d4150b37fe49d8/dataset_sentinel_01.png)   

Sentinel-1 SLC IW: Single Look Complex (SLC) Interferometric Wide (IW) Swath products consist  of  focused  SAR  data  geo-referenced  using orbit  and  attitude  data  from  the satellite  and  provided  in  zero-Doppler  slant-range  geometry. Mundi  Web  Services provides  the  complete  collection,  with  fresh  free  data  ONLINE  from  January  2018  with global  coverage,  and  from  January  2017  for  Europe.  A  rolling  policy  of  12  months  for World  and  24  months  for  Europe  is  currently  applied. We  are  making more  data available every day. 

The  IW  SLC  product used  in  this  tutorial contains  one  image  per  sub-swath,  per polarization  channel,  for  a  total  of  three  images.  Each  sub-swath  image  consists  of  a series  of  bursts,  where  each  burst  was  processed  as  a  separate  SLC  image.  The individually focused complex burst images are included, in azimuth-time order, into a singlesub-swath image, with black-fill demarcation in between as can be seen below:

![dataset_sentinel_02](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_02.png)

Image: [https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_02.png](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_02.png)    

Sentinel-2: The   Sentinel-2   L2A   data   is   atmospherically   corrected   using   Sen2Cor processor and PlanetDEM Digital Elevation Model (DEM). L2A products are published 48–60 hours after the L1C products and available for you to browse throughour Mundi Web Services Geodata UI.The S2-L2A product used in this tutorial consists of only three images representing the true composite color that use bands of visible light red (B04), green (B03), and blue (B02) in  the corresponding red, green and blue color channels, resulting in a natural colored [result.It](http://result.It) is a good representation of the Earth as humans would see it naturally as can be seen below:

![dataset_sentinel_03](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_03.png)

Image: [https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_03.png](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_03.png)  

The data will be used for Unsupervised KMeans image classification. This is a composite application, using existing training and classification applications. The SharkKMeans model is used.

![dataset_sentinel_04]( https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_04.png)

[https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_04.png](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_04.png)

This is the overall process until the image classification has been created and is available for download.

![dataset_sentinel_05]( https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_05.png)

Image: [https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_05.png](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_05.png)  

This algorithm is intended to be used in a Compute-to-Data environment, so you will not be able to directly access it. After processing the application you will be able to download the result.

If you want to download the sample files for your local installation and replication, you will need to open a free Mundi account here to access the satellite data: [https://mundiwebservices.com](https://mundiwebservices.com/)   

If you need support, please use the Mundi Helpdesk: [https://mundiwebservices.com/contact](https://mundiwebservices.com/contact)

To actually view the result images from the computation you will need the Monteverdi Image Viewer that is available for Linux, Mac and Windows machines. It is included in the Orfeo Package here: [https://www.orfeo-toolbox.org/download/](https://www.orfeo-toolbox.org/download/)

# Metadata FULL ATOS application



## Title

FULL - Copernicus Sentinel Data Fusion with CNES Orfeo toolbox

## Keywords

GaiaX, space, imaging, remote sensing, application, hackathon, demonstration, OTB, ESA, Copernicus, SAR

## Timeout

1 day

## Description

Important:

This is the “full” version for the 1st Gaia-X Hackathon. It is very resource intensive and thus has been priced prohibitive as only a limited number of parallel runs can be handled by our demonstration infrastructure. This “full” version is used illustrate the functionality of Compute-to-Data and the Data Exchange Logging Service and Data Audit Trails in Gaia-X and that Compute-to-Data is able to handle intensive jobs.

OTB application features came from the C++ library classes. They meet the users’ demands through simplified access and factoring requirements in data processing. They allow, among other things, to carry out the following operations:

- Access  to  data:  read/write  most  satellite  image  formats,  access  metadata,  read/write vector formats (shp, kml, etc.), digital terrain models, lidar data;
- Basic image manipulation: extraction, pixel-to-pixel calculations;
- Filtering: signal processing for optical and radar imaging;
- Feature extraction: textures (Haralick, Structural Feature Set [SFS]), edge detection, points of interest,  alignments,  lines,  descriptors  (Scale-Invariant  Feature  Transform  [SIFT],  Speeded Up Robust Features [SURF]);  
- Image segmentation: region growing, watershed, level set, mean-shift;
- Classification:  K-means,  support  vector  machine,  random  forests,  as  well  asmost recent machine learning algorithms;
- Detection of changes between images;
- Orthorectification, cartographic projections;
- Calculation of radiometric indices: vegetation, water, soil, etc.

### Intended use

This application is used to process images from Sentinel-1 SLC IW and Sentinel 2 L2A over the metropolitan area around Marseille, France. The figure below shows the extent and location of the Sentinel 2 data (red), the Sentinel 1 data (yellow), and the area of interest (blue).

![dataset_sentinel_01](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/97e4c2954cc86043d4f02f9f99d4150b37fe49d8/dataset_sentinel_01.png)

Image: https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/97e4c2954cc86043d4f02f9f99d4150b37fe49d8/dataset_sentinel_01.png   

Sentinel-1 SLC IW: Single Look Complex (SLC) Interferometric Wide (IW) Swath products consist  of  focused  SAR  data  geo-referenced  using orbit  and  attitude  data  from  the satellite  and  provided  in  zero-Doppler  slant-range  geometry. Mundi  Web  Services provides  the  complete  collection,  with  fresh  free  data  ONLINE  from  January  2018  with global  coverage,  and  from  January  2017  for  Europe.  A  rolling  policy  of  12  months  for World  and  24  months  for  Europe  is  currently  applied. We  are  making more  data available every day. 

The  IW  SLC  product used  in  this  tutorial contains  one  image  per  sub-swath,  per polarization  channel,  for  a  total  of  three  images.  Each  sub-swath  image  consists  of  a series  of  bursts,  where  each  burst  was  processed  as  a  separate  SLC  image.  The individually focused complex burst images are included, in azimuth-time order, into a singlesub-swath image, with black-fill demarcation in between as can be seen below:

![dataset_sentinel_02](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_02.png)

Image: https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_02.png   

Sentinel-2: The   Sentinel-2   L2A   data   is   atmospherically   corrected   using   Sen2Cor processor and PlanetDEM Digital Elevation Model (DEM). L2A products are published 48–60 hours after the L1C products and available for you to browse throughour Mundi Web Services Geodata UI.The S2-L2A product used in this tutorial consists of only three images representing the true composite color that use bands of visible light red (B04), green (B03), and blue (B02) in  the corresponding red, green and blue color channels, resulting in a natural colored [result.It](http://result.It) is a good representation of the Earth as humans would see it naturally as can be seen below:

![dataset_sentinel_03](https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_03.png)

Image: https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_03.png  

The data will be used for Unsupervised KMeans image classification. This is a composite application, using existing training and classification applications. The SharkKMeans model is used.

![dataset_sentinel_04]( https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_04.png)

https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_04.png  

This is the overall process until the image classification has been created and is available for download.

![dataset_sentinel_05]( https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_05.png)

Image: https://github.com/deltaDAO/files/raw/main/dataset_sentinel_05.png  

This algorithm is intended to be used in a Compute-to-Data environment, so you will not be able to directly access it. After processing the application you will be able to download the result.

## About the use case
This is a minimalist example of a BIDS App consisting of a Dockerfile and a simple entry point script (written in this case in Python) accepting the standard BIDS Apps command line arguments.

This application finds all structural (T1w) images, classifies tissue boundries, and removes the skull. The total brain volume for each participant is computed and the average brain volume in the dataset is written to *avg_brain_size.txt*.

This repository can be used as a template for new BIDS Apps following the Common Workflow Language and Workflow Description Language. Development is ongoing and the most up-to-date information can be found here: [https://docs.google.com/document/d/1E1Wi5ONvOVVnGhj21S1bmJJ4kyHFT7tkxnV3C23sjIE/](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1E1Wi5ONvOVVnGhj21S1bmJJ4kyHFT7tkxnV3C23sjIE/).
 
This application is supposed to run with example BIDS datasets listed on the Minimal Viable Gaia-X Health Domain.

You will be able to find out more about the extendable BIDS specification here: [https://bids-specification.readthedocs.io/en/stable/01-introduction.html](https://bids-specification.readthedocs.io/en/stable/01-introduction.html).

BIDS Extension Proposals (BEPs) extended BIDS specifications in a backwards compatible way, which is also a goal for the Gaia-X self-descriptions that will be continuously improved.

A few of the key elements of this ecosystem are the BIDS-validator [https://github.com/bids-standard/bids-validator](https://github.com/bids-standard/bids-validator), to automatically check datasets for adherence to the specification, OpenNeuro [https://openneuro.org/](https://openneuro.org/), as a database for BIDS formatted datasets, and BIDS-Apps [https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pcbi.1005209](https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pcbi.1005209), a collection of portable neuroimaging pipelines that understand BIDS datasets.


## Getting Started (Web 2.0 with local computation)


To get started, clone the repository into your working directory


git clone <https://github.com/BIDS-Apps/example> bids-example
Next you can build the Dockerfile


    cd bids-example

    docker build --no-cache -t gaia-x_bids/example-001 .


This will create a container with all of the required libraries and dependencies needed for the example to run. You will need a dataset to use this file, so use the datalad dataset aggregator and versoining utility to retrieve a dataset that conforms to BIDS from [http://openneuro.org](http://openneuro.org]). 

    datalad install <https://github.com/OpenNeuroDatasets/ds003763.git>
    cd ./ds003763
    datalad install -g -r $(pwd)

### First Level Analysis: Participant Operations

Once the data is done downloading you can start the docker container and execute it to strip the brains from each of the images for all the participants in the dataset.


    cd ../
    mkdir bids-example:output
    docker run -i -t -v /Users/admin/opscientia/projects/gaia-x_hackathon-1/ds003763:/bids_dataset:ro -v /Users/admin/opscientia/projects/gaia-x_hackathon-1/bids-example_output:/outputs gaia-x_bids/example-001 /bids_dataset /outputs participant --skip_bids_validator

Let’s dissect this command:

    docker run -i -t  

this ensures the container can receive standard input and outputs are printed to the terminal

    -v /Users/admin/opscientia/projects/gaia-x_hackathon-1/ds003763:/bids_dataset:ro

this maps the dataset on the local environment to the bids_dataset directory in the container as a read only source

    -v /Users/admin/opscientia/projects/gaia-x_hackathon-1/bids-example_output:/outputs

this maps the directory we’ve created for outputs from the BIDS-App to the internal directory for outputs

     gaia-x_bids/example-001 /bids_dataset /outputs participant --skip_bids_validator

this calls the BIDS-App we’ve build, gaia-x_bids/example-001 with the required input arguments, /bids_dataset /outputs, to execute each participate and skip the bids_validator due to a versioning bug.

When we run this command we will create a skullstripped image for each participant that will be written to the output directory.

### Second Level Analysis: Group Statistics
We can demonstrate a group level analysis by executing this command again with the group instead of the participant  option.

    docker run -i -t -v /Users/admin/opscientia/projects/gaia-x_hackathon-1/ds003763:/bids_dataset:ro -v /Users/admin/opscientia/projects/gaia-x_hackathon-1/bids-example_output:/outputs gaia-x_bids/example-001 /bids_dataset /outputs group --skip_bids_validator

Once this is complete, we can print the result to the terminal

    cat bids-example_output/avg_brain_size.txt
     Average brain size is 1.66032e+06 voxels

Algorithm is written in javascript. The algorithm will calculate averages, minimum and maximum for each array. If a date-field is given it will also link min and max values to their corresponding dates. 

![Status](https://img.shields.io/badge/Service-Online%20%2F%20Available-green)
![Type](https://img.shields.io/badge/Type-Simple%20Aggregation-blue)
![Type](https://img.shields.io/badge/Domain-Geoinformation-blue)

Dates are expected to have one of the following keys:

```
["date", "datetime", "day"]
``` 
The algorithm expects JSON input following the structure of our sample data set ([Demonstrator Data 📁 Weather Data / Sensor Data](https://market001.delta-dao.com/asset/did:op:c3C900b5299D16F4c6D34dC729ca8081ACA545CF)):
```
{
  "date": [...],
  "temperature": [...],
  "humidity": [...],
  "rain": [...],
  "windSpeed": [...],
  "windDir": [...],
  "invalidTest": ""
}
```
Any keys are processed, as long as the assigned value is an array of values. Non array values are not considered for calculations.

## Sample Output
The algorithm will log some system information about the wrapping container as well as progress on calculation. The result is a JSON file containing the calculated results:
```
{
  "fileCount": 1,
  "files": {
    "/data/inputs/c91B8Ee840fb70282C5B38a7d1654f9558D3822a/0": {
      "numLines": 123,
      "avg": {...},
      "min": {...},
      "max": {...}
    }
  }
}
```

## Additional Samples

- [Download Sample Data](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/deltaDAO/files/main/weatherForgedSample.json)
- [Download Sample Algorithm](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/deltaDAO/files/main/demo.js)

CC0 - we waive all copyrights. Feel free to use this sample to experiment and build a better data economy. 

## Contact

If you would like to know more about the Minimal Viable Gaia-X Demonstrator and the data service offerings listed here please contact us via contact@delta-dao.com or visit our website [deltaDAO AG](https://www.delta-dao.com/)

additionalInformation.description:
## About the use case
This open-access asset is used to provide an example for data-sovereign computation of health data in the Gaia-X European Health Data Space and a demonstration of metadata standards in the medical imaging domain.

This dataset is formatted for interoperable applications following the BIDS (brain imaging data structure), as described here: [https://www.nature.com/articles/sdata201644](https://www.nature.com/articles/sdata201644) and here [https://bids.neuroimaging.io/](https://bids.neuroimaging.io/). Additional pipelines and workflows are available on-demand through the BIDS-Apps Portal [https://bids-apps.neuroimaging.io/about/ ](https://bids-apps.neuroimaging.io/about/).

You will be able to find our more about the extendable BIDS specification here: [https://bids-specification.readthedocs.io/en/stable/01-introduction.html](https://bids-specification.readthedocs.io/en/stable/01-introduction.html). BIDS Extension Proposals (BEPs) may extend BIDS specifications for backwards compatibility, meeting one of the goals for continuosly improving Gaia-X self-descriptions.

A few of the key elements of this ecosystem are the BIDS-validator [https://github.com/bids-standard/bids-validator](https://github.com/bids-standard/bids-validator) , to automatically check datasets for adherence to the specification, OpenNeuro [https://openneuro.org/](https://openneuro.org/) , as a database for BIDS formatted datasets, and BIDS-Apps [https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pcbi.1005209](https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pcbi.1005209), a collection of portable neuroimaging pipelines that automatically parse BIDS datasets and deploy autonomous workflows on cloud services.

## About the data
The dataset contains fMRI data from a heartbeat detection task in 30 participants aged 40–65 years, with no history of cardiovascular events, such as stroke or myocardial infarction, and no severe white matter hyperintensities according to structural MRI (modified Fazekas score of 2 or less).

Heartbeat detection task is described in the following publications:

Dobrushina, Olga R., Arina, G. A., Dobrynina, L. A., Suslina, A. D., Solodchik, P. O., Belopasova, A. V. Krotenkova, M. V. (2020). The ability to understand emotions is associated with interoception‐related insular activation and white matter integrity during aging. Psychophysiology, 57(3), e13537. [https://doi.org/10.1111/psyp.13537](https://doi.org/10.1111/psyp.13537)

Krotenkova, M. V. (2020). The interrelation between interoception and emotional intelligence: a functional neuroimaging study. Zh Vyssh Nerv Deiat I P Pavlova, 70(2), 206–216. [https://doi.org/10.31857/s0044467720020069](https://doi.org/10.31857/s0044467720020069) (in Russian, with full description of stimuli material, which was also presented in Russian)

The file participants.tsv contains data on interoceptive accuracy (IAcc).

27 participants also underwent rubber hand illusion. The data is contained in participants.tsv: "drift_emerg_15" corresponds to the proprioceptive drift after 15 s from the onset of emergence phase, "test_own_15" and "control_own_15" correspond to the sum of test and control questions from the ownership questionary after 15 s from the onset of emergence phase. Publication with detailed task description is under review, reference will be provided later.

Each key is assigned to an array of values, except the `invalidTest` key, which demonstrates an invalid value for testing purposes with our algorithm: [Demonstrator Algorithm 🧮 Weather Data / Sensor Data](https://market001.delta-dao.com/asset/did:op:Fe0f741E188F025178BCFAeef7cE0854FaAF4d86)

```
  },

  },

    max: 12
  },

}
```

main.name: Demonstrator Data 📁 Weather Data / Sensor Data

additionalInformation.description: This is a minimalist example of a BIDS App consisting of a Dockerfile and a simple entry point script (written in this case in Python) accepting the standard BIDS Apps command line arguments.

This open-access asset is used to provide an example for data-sovereign computation of health data in the Gaia-X European Health Data Space and a demonstration of metadata standards in the medical imaging domain.

About the use case
This is a minimalist example of a BIDS App consisting of a Dockerfile and a simple entry point script (written in this case in Python) accepting the standard BIDS Apps command line arguments.
This application finds all structural (T1w) images, classifies tissue boundries, and removes the skull. The total brain volume for each participant is computed and the average brain volume in the dataset is written to avg_brain_size.txt.
This is an algorithm used for testing purposes.
This is a dataset used for testing purposes

## The Vision

The future of data markets is embedded in the European Digital Single Market and the Gaia-X initiative, providing a European common infrastructure for data services. The challenge is to leverage the enormous potential of data without compromising European values, such as privacy of personal information, openness, inclusiveness, transparency and a cooperation based on trust in common values. To ensure this we need to engage, cooperate and come up with practical solutions that help us to achieve these goals for a better future and a new data economy for everyone.

## Specifications

Data is in JSON format. The data is randomly generated "weather" data in the following format:
```
{
  "date": [...],
  "temperature": [...],
  "humidity": [...],
  "rain": [...],
  "windSpeed": [...],
  "windDir": [...],
  "invalidTest": ""
}
```
Each key is assigned to an array of values, except the `invalidTest` key, which demonstrates an invalid value for testing purposes with our algorithm: [Demonstrator Algorithm 🧮 A European Data Economy in 2021](https://market001.delta-dao.com/asset/did:op:Fe0f741E188F025178BCFAeef7cE0854FaAF4d86)

The data is generated using the following configuration:
```
{
  temperature: {
    min: -10,
    max: 35
  },
  humidity: {
    min: 40,
    max: 100
  },
  rain: {
    min: 0,
    max: 20
  },
  windSpeed: {
    min: 0,
    max: 12
  },
  windDir: ["N", "NE", "E", "SE", "S", "SW", "W", "NW"]
}
```

## Additional Samples

- Download [Sample #1](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/deltaDAO/files/main/weatherForgedSample.json)
- Download [Sample #2](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/deltaDAO/files/main/weatherForgedSample.json)

## The Vision

## Specifications

Algorithm is written in javascript. The algorithm will calculate averages, minimum and maximum for each array. If a date-field is given it will also link min and max values to their corresponding dates. Dates are expected to have one of the following keys:
```
["date", "datetime", "day"]
``` 
The algorithm expects JSON input following the structure of our sample data set ([Demonstrator Data 📁 A European Data Economy in 2021](https://market001.delta-dao.com/asset/did:op:c3C900b5299D16F4c6D34dC729ca8081ACA545CF)):

```
{
  "date": [...],
  "temperature": [...],
  "humidity": [...],
  "rain": [...],
  "windSpeed": [...],
  "windDir": [...],
  "invalidTest": ""
}
```
Any keys are processed, as long as the assigned value is an array of values. Non array values are not considered for calculations.

## Sample Output
The algorithm will log some system information about the wrapping container as well as progress on calculation. The result is a JSON file containing the calculated results:
```
{
  "fileCount": 1,
  "files": {
    "/data/inputs/c91B8Ee840fb70282C5B38a7d1654f9558D3822a/0": {
      "numLines": 123,
      "avg": {...},
      "min": {...},
      "max": {...}
    }
  }
}
```

additionalInformation.description:
Simple algorithm written in JavaScript/Node.js counting the rows in a `csv` file. Outputs the result in the compute log.

### Expected Input

- `csv`
- more coming soon

### Changelog

`v1.0.0`

- initial release

A data set documenting fish population in Berlin, Germany with species and endangerment according to the Berlin Red List, status 2003 to 2013.

### Data Basis

- Fishing in a total of 153 water bodies in Berlin between 2003 and 2013 with more than 900 individual fishes
- Fishing in small bodies of water at least once, some of the larger ones several times a year at different times of the year, as of 2013
- Fisheries statistics from the Berlin Fisheries Office
  Water map of the water register, status: 03/2014

### Data Format

`csv`

### License

[Data licence Germany – attribution – version 2.0](https://www.govdata.de/dl-de/by-2-0) / Geoportal Berlin / Fischfauna 2013 (Umweltatlas)
